job_title: Low Level Management in Grinnell, IA
pros: I have enormous flexibility, a fantastic boss, and the ability essentially choose what I work on during the day. I work with easy-going people who take their work seriously but have fun doing so. Overwhelmingly I have been treated fairly in all aspects of the work I do, and for the most part feel appreciated. I have had the opportunity to work in many departments, and have enjoyed that freedom.
cons: There is a huge separation in how staff and faculty salaries are handled. While it is likely necessary, that doesn't ease the emotional pain of seeing faculty receive 5-6% raises and staff receive 1-2% raises. Core benefits are outstanding, but there are some benefits that are not evenly applied across the institution. Things like summer 10-hour, 4-day work weeks are offered to some but not all departments. Some but not all departments have a dress code. Some but not all employees are encouraged to take advantage of professional development and wellness benefits. Management is very uneven. A few amazing managers/leaders, and a lot of really bad managers/non-leaders in leadership positions. Almost no room for career growth.

review_title: Self-Governed Jobs, at least they want you to believe
pros: Work with great students across the college community.
cons: Facing off with administrators is tiresome and draining.

pros:
Easy job for the most part
Looks good on resume
cons: Can be tedious and bad pay

pros: Great college, gave a lot of opportunities
cons: Very desolate location, far away from most major points.

pros: Great town and community overall
cons: There is lack of direction sometimes

pros: Flexible work hours, team-oriented, goal and mission driven, accountable and supportive environment

pros: flexible hours, better pay than most
cons: bad working conditions, very little breaks

review_title: No longer a nice place to work.
pros: If you like the small town feel, the city is awesome. The people are welcoming and helpful. The benefits received at Grinnell College are very good, but also comparable to other college/university work.
cons: The current president/Office of the President is mismanaging its people. They have spent over a million dollars on three separate outside consultants that all told them that the leadership is causing the current problems, and they did not listen. Employees fear for their jobs due to seeing others blamed and fired for no reason. They have tried to outsource crucial departments to disastrous consequences. Morale is at an all time low. Even the student government is upset with the "bulldozer tactics" of this administration. All but one Vice President has quit since this president took over. There are massive resignations of key members of staff. HR has no idea what they are doing and have been sued. The pay scale is low, even for Iowa.

review_title: A difficult place to adapt to as far as the culture is concerned.
pros: Great benefits. Great support staff coworkers. Decent pay.  Nice facilities to work in.  Lots of free events to attend and free use of the state of the art fitness facilities.
cons: Severe senior leadership problems. Low morale in many departments due to extreme salary disparity. Definitely a place where who you know gets you somewhere.  Overworked, and they are still getting rid of people by saying they aren't needed and then sparsing out work to others who can't even get their own work done.

review_title: Decent part time job for a student
pros: It was very easy for me to get a lab teaching assistant job in the physics department while I was a student there. Profs are very friendly and lenient.
cons: Sometimes the position seemed a little too unstructured for the lab positions. Sometimes I wouldn't know what lab I was supposed to be assisting with until I walked into the room but that wasn't a huge deal for me.

pros:
Great environment; Grinnell makes sure to hire smart, competent workers.

Relaxed work.

As a college, it's progressive and will try new technologies.
cons: Poorly managed.  Micromanagers and "idea guys" are an impediment sometimes to effective functioning of the department.

review_title: Best benefits of any employer in town.
pros: College contributes 10% of wage to 403 whether you contribute or not. Health benefits start the first day of the month after you start. So if you start on the 1st Monday of the month, you get health insurance day one!
cons: You have to wait 6 months before you are able to take any paid time off.

pros: Everyone is helpfull, the pay is generous (considering the amount of work done and the fun had) and it's overall a great experience.
cons: Sometimes the people asking for help from the TCs don't really understand what we say. They also sometimes come with very stupid problems. But it happens so infrequently it's not a big deal.

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Grinnell, IA
pros: College supports work of VAPs, funding for conference travel, pedagogical support, (almost) same benefits as TT. Great location for young families, good work/life policies.
cons: Can be isolating place to live, especially for young single & queer professionals. Some departments are much better than others at supporting VAPs

review_title: Comprehensive education providing students of all backgrounds many opportunities.
